This paper formalizes the "linear representation hypothesis" by proposing a geometric framework that connects the subspace hypothesis (e.g., word2vec analogies) with practical techniques like linear probing and activation steering. It introduces two formal definitions of linear representation: one in the output (unembedding) space, linked to measurement (linear probing), and another in the input (embedding) space, linked to intervention (activation steering). The core of the framework is the "causal inner product," a novel inner product that respects the causal separability of concepts (i.e., concepts that can vary independently are orthogonal). This causal inner product unifies the embedding and unembedding representations, allowing for the construction of probes and steering vectors using counterfactual pairs. Experiments with LLaMA-2 demonstrate the existence of these linear representations, the effectiveness of the causal inner product in capturing semantic structure, and how these representations enable both interpretation (via probing) and control (via steering) of LLM behavior.

*   The paper formalizes the "linear representation hypothesis" by defining linear representations in both input (embedding) and output (unembedding) spaces.

*   The formalizations connect the subspace notion of linear representation to measurement (linear probing) via unembedding representations and to intervention (activation steering) via embedding representations.
*   Empirical results with LLaMA-2 validate the existence of these linear representations and demonstrate that the causal inner product effectively captures semantic structure and enables model interpretation and control.
